DOCNAME: DENESOSKI v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
JUDGES: Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE ORG ( “ the first - instance court ” ) convicted the applicant and PERSON of misdemeanours punishable under sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the DATE LAW ( see “ Relevant domestic law ” below ) . They were fined MONEY ( ORG ) . The court also ordered a security measure in respect of PERSON , namely confiscation of a car which he had imported free of customs duties ( “ the confiscation order ” ) . On DATE ORG overturned that decision and suspended the misdemeanour proceedings since they had not been instituted by a competent authority .
On DATE a fresh application for misdemeanour proceedings was lodged against the applicant and PERSON , now under LAW ( see “ Relevant domestic law ” below ) .

On DATE the first - instance court found the applicant and PERSON A. guilty and fined them MKD CARDINAL,CARDINAL each . It observed that PERSON had imported the above - mentioned car free of customs duties in DATE . Under the applicable rules , the car should not have been disposed of for DATE after being imported . However , PERSON had transferred the car to a company ORG under an uncertified investment agreement ( договор за вложување ) . The court further established that on DATE , at CARDINAL , CARDINAL a.m. , the police had stopped the applicant while he was driving the car . The court ruled that the applicant knew or , in the circumstances , ought to have known that the car had been imported free of customs duties and that he could not use it . By a rectifying decision of DATE the confiscation order was issued in respect of PERSON On DATE ORG quashed these decisions and remitted the case for fresh consideration .

On DATE the applicant was found guilty of committing an offence punishable under the DATE LAW and was fined MKD CARDINAL . The confiscation order was issued again in respect of PERSON This decision was set aside on DATE .

On DATE the first - instance court found the applicant guilty and imposed the same fine . Relying on the evidence admitted in the first set of proceedings , the court found the applicant ’s conduct to be in breach of section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the DATE LAW . It established that on DATE at TIME , the applicant had been driving the car even though he knew or , in the circumstances , ought to have known that he could not use it given the preferential customs regime under which it had been imported . The court further stayed the proceedings in respect of PERSON since the DATE time - bar provided for in the DATE LAW had expired . In this connection , it established that on CARDINAL DATE Mr A. had transferred the car to company ORG although he was legally not supposed to dispose of it until after DATE . Lastly , the court issued the confiscation order in respect of PERSON as holder of title to the car .

The applicant appealed , submitting , inter alia , that the prosecution was time - barred , that his conviction was based on the DATE LAW , which was not in force at the date of the purported offence , namely DATE , that no evidence for his guilt had been presented nor any reason given in respect of the confiscation order and the fine imposed .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . It held that there was sufficient evidence of his guilt ; that it was irrelevant when the applicant had acquired factual possession of the car since the offence was regarded as being committed on DATE and that the DATE time - bar , specified in the DATE LAW , had not expired in the applicant ’s case . It further stated that the confiscation order had been lawful . No comment was made on the applicant ’s complaint that his conviction had been based on the DATE LAW .
On DATE this decision was served on the applicant .

On DATE the first - instance court dismissed PERSON claim for restitution of the car . It further regarded the applicant ’s claim submitted on the same ground as having been withdrawn . On DATE ORG upheld this decision .

Section CARDINAL of the DATE LAW identified persons eligible to import goods free of customs duties . A person concerned was obliged to pay the customs levies if he or she , within DATE after the import , intended to sell or to transfer to another person or to use the goods concerned for a purpose other than those for which the customs exemption or customs privilege had been granted .

According to section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , an enterprise or other legal entity would be fined by an amount of CARDINAL to CARDINAL times the evaded customs duty or CARDINAL to CARDINAL times the value of the undeclared goods if , before the expiration of the DATE time - limit , it had sold , transferred to another person or used the goods concerned for a purpose other than those for which the customs exemption had been granted .

Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL provided that an enterprise or other legal entity which bought , sold , accepted as a gift , retained , used or held on any ground the goods concerned , although it knew or in the circumstances ought to have known , that an offence had been committed , inter alia , under section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , would be sentenced to the same penalty as the offender . Under paragraph CARDINAL of this provision the same applied to individuals , both nationals and foreigners .

Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the DATE LAW provided that goods free of customs duties could not , within DATE after being imported and without import levies having been paid , be sold , transferred to another person or used for a purpose other than that for which the customs exemption had been granted .

Under section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , an individual was to be fined by an amount of CARDINAL times the evaded customs duty or CARDINAL times the value of the goods if he or she , contrary to CARDINAL and without having paid the customs duty , sold , transferred to another person or used goods for a purpose other than that for which the customs exemption had been granted .

Section CARDINAL § § CARDINAL and CARDINAL provided that legal entities which , in relation to the activity pursued , bought , sold , accepted as a gift , retained or for transport purposes , held , used or secured possession of goods in respect of which it knew or , in the circumstances ought to have known , that an offence under sections CARDINAL - CARDINAL had been committed , would be sentenced to the same penalty as the offender . That provision applied likewise to individuals .
The date when the DATE LAW was to enter into force was postponed on several occasions . By a law of DATE ( Official Gazette no . CARDINAL ) , it became applicable as of DATE .
